differential.history: premature neonate weighing less than 1500 g; feeding intolerance, apnoea, lethargy, bloody stools
differential.exam: abdominal distension, tenderness, abdominal wall erythema, haematochezia, bradycardia

test.name: FBC
test.result: leukocytosis or leukopenia, anaemia, thrombocytopenia

comments.para: Decreased WBC count may be more ominous than leukocytosis. Anaemia may result with significant haematochezia.

test.name: blood culture
test.result: negative

comments.para: Bacterial sepsis should be excluded.

test.name: serum electrolyte panel
test.result: hyponatraemia

test.name: abdominal x-ray
test.result: dilated loops of bowel, pneumatosis intestinalis, portal venous gas, free air, fixed loop of bowel, lack of normal intestinal gas pattern

comments.para: Important to obtain both AP and left lateral decubitus views.

test.name: abdominal ultrasound
test.result: fluid collections, ascites

comments.para: Useful for diagnosing fluid collections that may represent perforation or abscess.

differential.history: FHx of peptic ulcer disease; weight loss, vomiting, anorexia, and intermittent epigastric pain, usually related to eating meals; pain often nocturnal and usually relieved by antacids; melaena and/or haematemesis if blood vessel perforated
differential.exam: unremarkable or epigastric tenderness; melaena may be present on rectal examination or occult bleeding on stool haemoccult test

test.name: FBC
test.result: normal or leukocytosis; anaemia present if sustained blood loss

test.name: erect chest x-ray
test.result: usually normal

comments.para: Ordered to rule out gastric or duodenal perforation (demonstrated by free air under the diaphragm).

test.name: upper GI series with water-soluble contrast
test.result: mucosal defect(s) consistent with ulcer or free intraperitoneal contrast consistent with perforation

comments.para: Gastric and duodenal ulcers can sometimes be visualised with x-ray imaging. Contrasted imaging studies can indicate location and depth of ulcers. This may serve as an initial test prior to the more definitive endoscopy.

test.name: upper GI endoscopy
test.result: mucosal inflammation, ulceration, and haemorrhage

comments.para: Peptic ulcer disease, generalised gastritis, and haemorrhage can be confirmed with upper GI endoscopy. Endoscopy also enables several techniques to be used to control bleeding vessels. Endoscopy can also provide biopsies if malignancy suspected and for culture of H pylori.
Endoscopy should be performed urgently if bleeding is suspected (prior to any contrast radiological studies). Contrast may interfere with the assessment of the mucosa.

test.name: Helicobacter pylori breath test or stool antigen test
test.result: positive result if H pylori present

comments.para: Generally not necessary if endoscopy and biopsy are being performed; however, in places where endoscopy is not readily available, it may be of use to determine whether a patient needs referral to a specialist. A blood test for H pylori is not useful in children.

differential.history: hx of trauma; abdominal pain may be out of proportion to examination findings; may have multiple complaints; hx may suggest child abuse or non-accidental trauma (e.g., inconsistent or changing history)
differential.exam: abdominal tenderness; skin marks reflecting mechanism of injury (e.g., seatbelt mark); referred left shoulder pain (due to splenic injury); blood at the urethral meatus, or haematuria (indicate urinary tract or kidney injury); signs of non-accidental trauma may be present (e.g., cigarette burns, subdural haemorrhages in an infant/young toddler)

test.name: FBC
test.result: may be normal or show decreased haematocrit and haemoglobin

comments.para: Patients with acute-onset haemorrhage may have normal haematocrit and haemoglobin values.

test.name: abdominal CT scan with intravenous contrast
test.result: variable

comments.para: This is the diagnostic test of choice for the identification of solid organ injuries, especially to liver, kidney, and/or spleen. Oral contrast is usually not necessary when scanning a patient for trauma.

test.name: chest x-ray
test.result: may be normal or show compatible thoracic injury (e.g., pulmonary contusion, pneumothorax); free air under diaphragm (suggests perforation)

test.name: abdominal ultrasound
test.result: variable; may show free fluid in abdominal cavity

comments.para: Focused abdominal sonography for trauma (FAST) may be useful in patients with blunt abdominal trauma who are haemodynamically unstable. Presence of large amounts of free fluid indicates need for immediate operative intervention. FAST in haemodynamically stable patients with blunt abdominal trauma has a less certain impact as a negative scan does not preclude injury.

test.name: full skeletal x-rays
test.result: variable

comments.para: Skeletal survey identifies previous skeletal injuries and should be obtained if there is a high suspicion of non-accidental trauma. This should only be performed to provide adjunctive diagnoses to support an initial injury and suspicion of abuse.

differential.history: recurrent, episodic RUQ pain, may radiate to the back and is classically colicky in nature; often occurs after eating, particularly fatty foods; nausea, vomiting, and anorexia may be present; persistent pain and fever may signify acute cholecystitis; referred pain to right shoulder can occur; presence of risk factors (e.g., sickle cell disease, cystic fibrosis)
differential.exam: right subcostal region tenderness; positive Murphy's sign (during palpation, deep inspiration causes pain to suddenly become worse and produces inspiratory arrest); palpable distended, tender gallbladder; fever suggests acute cholecystitis; jaundice rare

test.name: RUQ ultrasound
test.result: gall stones; thickened gallbladder wall (>4 mm); pericholecystic fluid; may also see ultrasonographic Murphy's sign

comments.para: Definitive test for imaging the gallbladder.

Certain features are important to note when assessing a patient with suspected cholecystitis including the presence or absence of gallstones and/or sludge; the absence of gallstones in a patient with a history suggestive of cholecystitis may be indicative of biliary dyskinesia. In addition, gallbladder wall thickness: thickened gallbladder wall is suggestive of inflammation. Pericholecystic fluid refers to the presence of fluid around the gallbladder and is suggestive of acute inflammation. The absence of fluid in the presence of gallstones and/or gallbladder wall thickening is suggestive of chronic cholecystitis or biliary colic. Sonographic Murphy's sign refers to the presence of Murphy's sign with sonographic compression of the gallbladder and is suggestive of acute inflammation of the gallbladder.

test.name: LFTs
test.result: may see elevated alk phos, bilirubin and aminotransferase

comments.para: May be normal or marginally increased; if significantly elevated, other aetiologies (such as hepatitis, choledocholithiasis, or cholangitis) may be present.
It is important to note the direct bilirubin concentration, which is the fraction that is elevated with common duct obstruction.

test.name: FBC
test.result: normal WBC (suggests cholelithiasis) or leukocytosis (suggests acute cholecystitis)

test.name: abdominal x-ray
test.result: opacities in RUQ consistent with gallstones

comments.para: If sufficiently radio-opaque, it may be possible to identify gallstones on a plain abdominal film.

test.name: hepatobiliary iminodiacetic acid (HIDA) scan
test.result: non-filling gallbladder

comments.para: Considered a useful adjunct in the diagnosis of cholecystitis. The classical finding is non-filling of the gallbladder. Prolonged fasting may result in a false-positive test.

differential.history: multiple sexual partners, sexual intercourse with infected individuals (hepatitis B and/or C), travel to developing countries, pregnant (hepatitis E); early disease: malaise, muscle and joint aches, fever, nausea, vomiting, diarrhoea, headache, anorexia, dark urine, pale stool, abdominal pain; late disease: weight loss, easy bruising and bleeding tendencies
differential.exam: jaundice; early disease: tender hepatosplenomegaly, lymphadenopathy; late disease: generalised wasting, cachexia, gynaecomastia, ascites, altered sensorium, asterixis, or decreased deep tendon reflexes, caput medusa, ascites, hepatosplenomegaly, congestion secondary to right heart failure

test.name: serum LFTs
test.result: high direct bilirubin, AST, ALT, alk phos and gamma-GT

comments.para: Although transaminases may be elevated, the level is not a good correlate for severity of infection; it indicates liver damage.

test.name: serum IgM anti-HAV
test.result: positive if acute hepatitis A infection

test.name: serum hepatitis B surface antigen (HBsAg)
test.result: positive if hepatitis B infection

comments.para: Positive result appears in serum 1 to 10 weeks after an acute exposure and disappears when infection abates.

test.name: serum hepatitis B core antigen (HBcAg)
test.result: positive if hepatitis B infection

comments.para: An intracellular antigen that is found in infected hepatocytes.

test.name: serum hepatitis B e antigen (HBeAg)
test.result: positive if hepatitis B infection

comments.para: Patients with a positive result are considered highly infective for hepatitis B.

test.name: serum HCV RNA
test.result: positive if hepatitis C infection

comments.para: Identifies acute or chronic infection with hepatitis C virus. Progression to chronic disease after acute infection is highly likely. Significant risk for hepatocellular carcinoma.
Patients should be at least 1 year old prior to testing for hepatitis C.

test.name: serum total (IgM and IgG) anti-HDV antibodies
test.result: positive if hepatitis D infection

comments.para: Performed by enzyme-linked or radio-immunoassay. Hepatitis D is a defective virus and can only replicate in the presence of co-infection or superinfection with HBV.

test.name: serum anti-HEV IgM antibodies
test.result: positive if acute hepatitis E infection

test.name: FBC
test.result: low or normal platelet count

comments.para: A low platelet count is suggestive of portal hypertension.

test.name: coagulation profile (PT, INR)
test.result: May be elevated or normal

comments.para: In cases of severe hepatitis, liver synthetic function as measured by coagulation parameters may be compromised, reflected by increased PT and INR.

differential.history: hx of previous negative work-up for cholelithiasis common; recurrent RUQ pain; nausea and vomiting; symptoms may or may not be associated with eating
differential.exam: may be equivocal; RUQ tenderness

test.name: LFTs
test.result: normal AST, ALT, alk phos, and bilirubin

test.name: RUQ ultrasound
test.result: normal

comments.para: Gallstones should not be demonstrated in patients with biliary dyskinesia.

test.name: hepatobiliary iminodiacetic acid (HIDA) scan
test.result: decreased (<35%) gallbladder ejection fraction

comments.para: Considered the diagnostic test of choice.

The ejection fraction of the gallbladder is measured after the administration of cholecystokinin (CCK); pain elicited after administration of CCK that mimics the patient's presenting symptoms may equate to a better outcome after cholecystectomy (if a cut-off of <15% is used).

differential.history: nausea, vomiting, epigastric pain radiating to back; acute-onset abdominal pain
differential.exam: epigastric or upper abdominal tenderness; tachycardia and hypotension in severe cases; discoloration around the umbilicus (positive Cullen's sign) or flanks (positive Grey-Turner's sign) in cases of haemorrhagic pancreatitis; small children may demonstrate increased irritability and abdominal distension only

test.name: amylase
test.result: 3 times upper limit of normal range

comments.para: Useful for following the biochemical course of the disease, as the half-life is much shorter than that of lipase.
Normal range: 35 to 118 units/L. Sensitivity of 75% to 92% and a specificity of 20% to 60% with a positive predictive value approaching 100%.
Levels start rising over the first 2 to 12 hours, peak at 48 hours, and return to normal within 3 to 5 days.

test.name: lipase
test.result: can be elevated if amylase normal

comments.para: Lipase is more sensitive (50% to 99%) and specific (86% to 100%) than amylase; however, the utility is limited in acute pancreatitis due to discrepancies in measurement method, patient selection, and cut-off point. Hence, the determination of lipase is not necessary in a patient with a clinical diagnosis of acute pancreatitis and 3 times the normal value of serum amylase. Its use can be helpful in patients with a clinical presentation suggestive of pancreatitis and normal amylase. Due to additional cost and lack of benefit in the majority of patients, utilising serum lipase in conjunction with serum amylase is considered inappropriate.

Levels start rising 4 to 8 hours after the onset of pain, peak at 24 hours, and last for 8 to 14 days. Patients with alcoholic pancreatitis have higher levels of lipase than those with gallstone pancreatitis.

test.name: bilirubin
test.result: normal or elevated

comments.para: An elevated bilirubin (specifically direct bilirubin) is suggestive of gallstone-induced pancreatitis. In addition, choledochal cysts are an important cause of pancreatitis in children.

test.name: abdominal ultrasound
test.result: may appear normal early in disease course; enlargement of the pancreas; peripancreatic oedema; dilated pancreatic duct; may show underlying biliary disease

comments.para: Ultrasound is a useful and commonly employed modality for the diagnosis of pancreatic disease in children, as there is no radiation exposure involved.
Permits concurrent assessment of the biliary system for cholelithiasis and/or choledocholithiasis that may be the underlying cause of pancreatitis.

test.name: CT scan abdomen with intravenous contrast
test.result: peripancreatic inflammation (fat stranding); may show gallstones

comments.para: Although this involves exposure to radiation, it is an excellent tool in the diagnosis of early pancreatitis. Ordered if patient is not improving with standard treatment or if complicated disease is suspected. Should not be ordered for uncomplicated cases of pancreatitis in which the patient is improving.
Allows better assessment of potential pancreatic necrosis (which would indicate more serious disease) and peripancreatic inflammation than is achievable with ultrasound.

differential.history: varied; may be hx of trauma; cysts either asymptomatic or dull, left-sided abdominal pain; infarction typically causes fever as well as pain, but occasionally asymptomatic; left-sided shoulder and/or chest pain; presence of risk factors for splenic infarction (sickle cell disease, high altitude)
differential.exam: may be vague LUQ tenderness

test.name: Doppler ultrasound
test.result: infarction or cyst on spleen

comments.para: Splenic infarcts appear as wedge-shaped defects. Blood flow is absent, with absence of Doppler signal. Cysts appear anechoic.

test.name: CT scan abdomen with intravenous contrast
test.result: infarction or cyst on spleen

comments.para: Splenic infarcts appear as wedge-shaped defects. Blood flow is absent, manifested as lack of contrast enhancement on CT scan.
Splenic cysts may also be visualised.

differential.history: hx of recurrent crampy abdominal pain associated with menstruation
differential.exam: lower abdominal tenderness; normal pelvic examination

test.name: none
test.result: diagnosis is clinical

test.name: CT scan abdomen/pelvis
test.result: normal; however, useful to rule out other diagnoses

test.name: abdominal/pelvic ultrasound
test.result: normal; however, useful to rule out other diagnoses

differential.history: FHx of nephrolithiasis and/or gout; intermittent, severe, colicky flank and/or abdominal pain; nausea and vomiting; gross or microscopic haematuria; urinary frequency/urgency; atypical presentation common in younger children
differential.exam: ipsilateral costovertebral angle and flank tenderness; tachycardia and hypotension in pain-controlled patient may suggest concurrent urosepsis

test.name: ultrasound of the urinary tract
test.result: calcification seen within urinary tract; possible dilated proximal ureter and hydronephrosis

comments.para: Ultrasound should be the first modality. As well as diagnosing nephrolithiasis, it can provide information on potential complications of obstruction such as hydronephrosis.

test.name: urinalysis
test.result: may be normal or dipstick-positive for leukocytes, nitrites, blood; microscopic analysis positive for WBCs, RBCs, or bacteria

comments.para: Patients with nephrolithiasis typically have blood in the urine. It is important to pay attention to other elements of the urine analysis, as the presence of white blood cells, leukocyte esterase, and nitrites may signify a concurrent urinary tract infection.

test.name: abdominal x-ray
test.result: radio-opaque stones

comments.para: If sufficiently radio-opaque, urinary stones may be visible on plain x-rays. Up to 85% of stones are visible, although uric acid stones are radiolucent.

test.name: non-contrast CT scan abdomen and pelvis
test.result: calcification seen in renal collecting system or ureter; possible dilated proximal ureter and hydronephrosis

comments.para: Highly sensitive for detection of nephrolithiasis and assessment of hydronephrosis. In addition, if stones are not seen, an alternative aetiology may be detected; frequently, nephrolithiasis detected on CT scan is a serendipitous finding for the investigation of other aetiologies of abdominal pain.

differential.history: acute-onset testicular pain; nausea, and vomiting; hx of recurrent episodes suggests repeated episodes of testicular torsion followed by spontaneous detorsion; hx of trauma may be present
differential.exam: tender, oedematous testicle; affected testicle may appear higher than unaffected testicle with horizontal lie; associated scrotal erythema and oedema; absent cremasteric reflex; usually no pain relief with elevation of the scrotum

test.name: grey-scale ultrasound
test.result: presence of fluid and the whirlpool sign (the swirling appearance of the spermatic cord from torsion as the ultrasound probe scans downward perpendicular to the spermatic cord)

comments.para: An ultrasound or other radiological test should not delay definitive treatment if the diagnosis of testicular torsion is highly suggested by history and physical examination.
The real-time whirlpool sign is the most specific sign of partial or complete testicular torsion.

test.name: power Doppler ultrasound
test.result: absent or decreased blood flow in the affected testicle; decreased flow velocity in the intratesticular arteries, increased resistive indices in the intratesticular arteries

comments.para: Can help quantify the strength of intratesticular blood flow.

Power Doppler is direction-sensitive, making it more likely to pick up blood flow than colour Doppler. The amount of flow detected in the normal testicle is usually greater using power Doppler than that detected when using colour Doppler. Power Doppler is up to 5 times more sensitive to blood flow than regular colour Doppler, and is the mode of choice to pick up slow-moving blood such as is seen in ovaries and testicles.

differential.history: acute onset of one-sided lower abdominal or pelvic pain; nausea and vomiting common; hx of frequent, similar episodes; fever rare
differential.exam: tender pelvic mass (adnexal); in patients old enough to undergo pelvic examination, cervical motion tenderness may be elicited; typically no vaginal discharge, but may be some mild to moderate vaginal bleeding

test.name: pelvic ultrasound
test.result: solid appearance of the ovary, unilateral ovarian enlargement, ovarian peripheral cystic structures, marked stromal oedema, fluid in the pouch of Douglas

test.name: colour Doppler
test.result: reduced or absent intraovarian blood flow

comments.para: Suggestive of ovarian torsion. Can help determine whether the flow in the ovary is impaired. However, specificity is poor.

test.name: CT scan abdomen and pelvis
test.result: enlarged, oedematous ovary with or without vascular enhancement; free fluid in pelvis

comments.para: CT scans can demonstrate adnexal masses and ischaemia of the ovary. Typically, ovarian torsion diagnosed by CT scan is a serendipitous finding during an attempt to identify other sources of abdominal pain.

differential.history: rupture usually spontaneous, can follow history of trauma or sexual intercourse; mild chronic lower abdominal discomfort may suddenly intensify
differential.exam: adnexal tenderness; adnexal size unremarkable due to collapsed cyst; peritonism may be present in lower abdomen and pelvis

test.name: pelvic ultrasound
test.result: complex mass appearance; fluid in the pouch of Douglas

comments.para: A complex mass appearance suggests a ruptured haemorrhagic cyst surrounded by a haematoma. Fluid in the pouch of Douglas is also indicative of a ruptured cyst.

differential.history: sexually active; multiple partners; hx may be suggestive of sexual abuse (particularly if young child); pain worse with sexual intercourse; dull, aching lower abdominal pain with or without dysuria; vaginal discharge, low-grade fever
differential.exam: temperature >38.3Â°C (101Â°F); cervical motion tenderness, adnexal or uterine tenderness, vaginal or cervical mucopurulent discharge

test.name: wet mount of vaginal secretions
test.result: polymorphonuclear leukocytes (PMNs) seen

comments.para: Presence of vaginal PMNs confirms vaginal infection. High predictive value but not specific for pathogens most likely to cause PID.

test.name: pelvic ultrasound
test.result: normal or may demonstrate endometritis, hydrosalpinx, pyosalpinx, tubo-ovarian abscess

comments.para: Ultrasound findings can be variable demonstrating any portion of the female reproductive organs.
Most common findings include pyosalpinx and tubo-ovarian abscess.

test.name: genetic probe or culture of vaginal secretions for Neisseria gonorrhoeae and Chlamydia trachomatis
test.result: positive result indicates presence of organisms

comments.para: Test should be ordered in any patient with suspected PID.

Specimens obtained from vaginal examination can be sent for testing. Urine tests should be not the initial test ordered, but may be necessary if a pelvic examination is not feasible (e.g., due to age of child).

test.name: HIV serology
test.result: positive or negative

comments.para: It is important to test for other sexually transmitted diseases during a work-up for PID, including HIV infection.

test.name: hepatitis studies
test.result: positive or negative

comments.para: It is important to test for other sexually transmitted diseases during a work-up for PID, including hepatitis B and C.

test.name: rapid plasma reagin (RPR)
test.result: positive or negative

comments.para: It is important to test for other sexually transmitted diseases during a work-up for PID, including syphilis.

test.name: laparoscopy
test.result: normal or may demonstrate endometritis, hydrosalpinx, pyosalpinx, tubo-ovarian abscess

comments.para: Laparoscopy is the preferred invasive method of diagnosis allowing direct visualisation of the gynaecological and abdominal structures. In addition, it may aid the diagnosis of Fitz-Hugh-Curtis syndrome.

differential.history: hx of previous ectopic pregnancy or miscarriage, fallopian tube or pelvic surgery, pelvic inflammatory disease (PID); lower abdominal pain, amenorrhoea, and vaginal bleeding
differential.exam: minimal abdominal tenderness and/or vaginal bleeding; pelvic examination may reveal a mass, eliciting cervical motion tenderness if haemoperitoneum is present; tubal rupture can cause haemodynamic instability

test.name: urine pregnancy test
test.result: positive

comments.para: Confirms pregnancy; although false-negative tests, depending on kit used, are known.

test.name: quantitative beta-hCG
test.result: positive

comments.para: A normal intrauterine pregnancy is typically visualised at beta-hCG levels between 1500 and 2500 IU/L (1500 and 2500 mIU/mL). If not, the likely differential diagnosis is ectopic pregnancy or miscarriage.

Serial beta-hCG measurement is usually used when the ultrasound is inconclusive and the initial beta-hCG is below the discriminatory zone (1500-2000 IU/L [1500-2000 mIU/mL]). An increase of at least 66% in 2 measurements over 48 hours is suggestive of a viable intrauterine pregnancy. An increase of <66% is suggestive of an ectopic pregnancy. A rapid and steady decline is indicative of a miscarriage.
A single serum measurement cannot exclude ectopic pregnancy or predict the risk of rupture unless it is <5 IU/L (<5 mIU/mL).

test.name: pelvic ultrasound
test.result: demonstrates free fluid in the pelvis and/or a periovarian mass

comments.para: With trained personnel, bedside pelvic ultrasound is a fast, reliable method to assess for ectopic pregnancy. Transvaginal ultrasound may be used to assess for intrauterine pregnancy.

An ectopic pregnancy may be characterised by an echogenic, cyst-like structure outside the uterus. Several ultrasound findings may be associated with early ectopic pregnancy such as tubal ring, extrauterine mass, extrauterine empty gestational sac, and haemosalpinx.

In an unstable patient, it is important not to delay treatment while waiting for an ultrasound. A quick and focused bedside ultrasound examination to assess for the presence of free fluid or blood may be helpful when ruptured ectopic pregnancy is suspected.

test.name: transvaginal ultrasound
test.result: presence or absence of intrauterine pregnancy

comments.para: Differentiates between different stages and types of miscarriage. Specific, fairly prognostic and would exclude other differential diagnoses of miscarriage.
Occasionally directly identifies ectopic pregnancy.
Usually used in conjunction with pelvic ultrasound in the setting of positive beta-hCG plus abdominal pain and/or vaginal bleeding.

test.name: type and screen
test.result: variable

differential.history: cough; purulent sputum production; upper respiratory tract symptoms (rhinorrhoea, sore throat, nasal congestion), shortness of breath, fever, and chills; splinting secondary to pain; vomiting, diarrhoea, anorexia
differential.exam: tachypnoea, cyanosis, decreased breath sounds, crackles/rales on auscultation, dullness on percussion; abdominal tenderness and distension without guarding or rebound

test.result: variable

comments.para: In patients with viral pneumonia, WBC count may be normal or decreased.

test.result: infiltration, consolidation, effusion

test.name: chest ultrasound
test.result: localised fluid collection

comments.para: May consider before proceeding to CT scan due to the lack of radiation exposure.

test.name: CT scan chest with intravenous contrast
test.result: consolidation of lung parenchyma; extraparenchymal fluid with loculations suggests empyema

comments.para: CT scan may better differentiate between empyema and simple effusion.

differential.history: recent pneumonia, fever, cough, chest pain; malaise, anorexia, weight loss, or fatigue may occur; presence of risk factors (immunocompromise, comorbidities predisposing to the development of pneumonia, pre-existing lung disease, iatrogenic interventions in the pleural space, male sex)
differential.exam: febrile, toxic patient, dullness on percussion, absence of breath sounds over affected area; abdominal tenderness and distension without guarding or rebound

test.name: chest x-ray
test.result: blunting of costophrenic angle or effusion on affected side, possible consolidation, pleurally based 'D' shape in empyema

comments.para: The presence of a loculated effusion suggests an empyema. There may be associated pulmonary consolidation due to pneumonia.

test.name: blood culture
test.result: positive for specific pathogens

comments.para: Blood cultures may be positive even if the pleural fluid culture is negative.
Should be taken before the initiation of antibiotics if the clinical state of the patient permits.

test.name: thoracentesis
test.result: frank pus in empyema, serous or cloudy in complicated parapneumonic effusions

comments.para: An effusion measuring >10 mm on a lateral decubitus chest x-ray, in association with evidence of infection, requires thoracentesis (pleural aspiration).
Aspiration of frank pus is diagnostic of empyema, and no other investigations are required to establish the diagnosis.

npce.title: RCT casts doubt on value of focused abdominal sonography for trauma (FAST) in haemodynamically stable children with blunt torso trauma

item.para: A new RCT compared FAST with standard care in children and adolescents with blunt torso trauma.
Previous research found FAST may be useful in assessment of children with blunt abdominal trauma who are haemodynamically unstable.

The new RCT raised uncertainty over the value of FAST for haemodynamically stable children and adolescents with blunt torso trauma. It found no significant difference in the proportion of abdominal CT scans, missed intra-abdominal injuries, length of stay in the accident and emergency department, and median hospital costs in the children assessed using FAST compared with those receiving standard care.
